PRESIDENT PATTON'S
MESSAGE.
When President Patton speaks, it behooves
every student to lend an attentive ear, not only
because all that he says is worthy of deepest
consideration, but also because if one does not
listen closely, one fails to hear almost every
fifth word. His style, however, is piquant, and
at times quaint. His premises and conclusions
are clearly marked, and without doubt he believes what he says. For a man to attempt to
speak of Morals and Religion" in any coherent manner, with all his notes for an hour's
talk on a sheet three by four is, forsooth, a
task before which even a Presbyterian minister might hesitate. But President Patton not
only showed that what he said was the product of deep personal thought, but—what is
more essential—he set his hearers to thinking
for themselves. His arguments were striking,
his conclusions are not lightly to be set aside,
and the question comes to every sincere man,
"How does all this affect. me? How am I to

No. xo

convert my convictions into actions ?"
Dr. Patton spoke of "Moral Obligation,"
of "The Good" and of "The Right." He
glanced at the various ethical schools, and
struck off many apt comparisons. He showed
in an incontestable manner that no adequate
idea of moral obligation can be had until you
enthrone the Almighty and put a moral Governor above you. 'Tis then, and then only, that
the idea of obligation can have any true influence in the amelioration of mankind. We find
in our nature a powerful tendency to degeneration, and if we are to journey toward perfection there must be not only an external
standard whereby our conduct may be judged,
but there must be also an equally powerful
force impelling us away from our natural tendencies. A standard of infinite good and right
by which man's finite doings may be counted
can come only from a true conception of the
attributes of an infinite being—a perfect personality. 'Tis in the presence of such conceptions that the edicts of that infinite being will
furnish the force necessary to raise man up out
of the mire of his natural tendencies. The
edict must get its force from the power of the
personality behind it. If you are going to control the personality of man and obtain morality, the law must he given with the thunder of
Mount Sinai, saying: "Thou shalt not."
Some people would lay aside religion and
consider morality as a separate idea. But the
earthquake that pulls the church down will
shake with equal force the foundations of the
ethical lecture hall. Take away religion and
morals will soon disappear. Albeit that morality is instructive, when once you have removed God you have abolished obligatory
morality forever, and all that you have left is
a morality of good form and good taste.
Under such conditions, how long, think ye,
would this world be a fit dwelling-place for
the children of men ?
President Patton omitted any fruitless discussion of "Determinism" or "Libertarianism," but insisted equally upon the infinite

sovereignty of God and upon the free agency
of man. On nothing else did he lay more
stress than upon the fact that there can be no
moral obligation unless there be a subject of
that obligation—free to feel, think and act.
All the morality of the universe resolves itself
into selfhood — the power of self-determination. We are not mere machines. It is necessary for us to realize fully that we can act of
our own accord, even against a prevailing
habit. In a man's character nature determines
much, and habit goes on and determines more,
yet they do not determine all ;
" holds its
own against both. We must have great actions;
let us then, as Emerson suggests, make our
own so. That man reaches the highest pinnacle of character who most truly and fully
translates into actions on this terrestial ball
the thoughts of the most high God.
We must not avoid facts. We must see that
there is a standard by which our actions arc
judged, and an end to which they will carry
us, if they be conformed to that standard. The
standard is the Right," the end the "Good."
Neither of these ideas is to be made- subordinate to the other. They are co-ordinate, and
mutually parallel. But what is the "Good ?"
Every man leans to that which is most desirable to him, and the logical conclusion is that
there is something supremely desirable. Some
seek wealth, because that brings surpassing
grandeur, or immunity from toil, they seek a
surplus of pleasure.
He who tortures his
memory with innumerable languages does the
same thing in a different way. Both seek happiness, and the result is the same, whether it
come from successful shop-keeping or successful word-monging. Is man's destiny, then,
but to be happy? If we look only at pleasure,
we are unable to distinguish between the
heaven of the hog and the saint's heaven. The
hog's manners are to us somewhat unconventional, but,could he speak, would he not reply
that he preferred the freedom of his trough to
the starched stiffness of our dining-rooms? We
cannot say that pleasure is the end of life, but
must find sonic more rational ground for happiness. The end toward which we strive is
moral perfection. In this matter no idea but
one of progress to higher goals can be

thought of. Drummond says : "It is only a
character which is itself developing that can
aid the evolution of the world and so fulfill the
end of life." To such a progress the end must
be infinite ; and this is God. So far as we can
see, the destiny of every part of everybody is
to become, by growth and development, a perfect part. Is it not the same for man as a
whole ? Self-realization is the "Good" to be
reached. The glory of God, which some consider the chief end of man, is not incompatible
with man's self-realization ; on the contrary,
it is to be reached through self-realization.
Since man is made in the image of God, and
God is perfect, the highest honor that man can
pay to God is earnestly to strive to reach the
same perfection.
If the ideal is to be of any value, we must
believe it to be attainable ; we must separate it
from the life of this world, and then we must
conceive another life in which to enjoy it.
Therefore, if the idea be attainable, and the
blackness of pessimism is upon those that
think not so, there must be God, freedom and
immortality. For it cannot be said that character will develop in all its fullness in this life.
That were a time far too short for an evolution
so glorious. We see here only the small green
blade which hut determines what we ultimately shall be. Ultimately—that is a long
way off, but not too long to take into reckoning. When the fires of the sun shall have
burned themselves to ashes, we shall not have
completed our cathedral of character, we shall
still be building.
Will the building last ?
Hear—" He that doeth the will of God abideth
forever."
CHARLES KEYSER

Contrary to our bold expectations, our representative 'champions seemed rather crestfallen during the last manoeuvre. The brilliant scheme of the rotary turret failed for lack
of points. The points on the immigration
question, as the reader may remember, were to
form the steel armor of this novel structure.
The general criticised with severe justice the
bearing of our troops. On the whole, these
symptoms gladden the Senate's spirits, as evident signs of final victory. For the very soldiers who wince and bow their heads as the
first shells are humming above them, will
coolly face the jaws of death's batteries on the
day of battle. Whereas premature bravado is
proverbially common with bad fighting stock.
By command of the general, different tactics

be followed by headache on the field. The

on

PROF. ADAMS' ADDRESS.
On the 18th of February, Professor Adams
delivered the Phi Beta Kappa oration at
William and Mary College on the study and
teaching of history. Professor Adams was
especially welcomed there as a guest since it
was largely due to the publication of a monograph by him, that public interest was revived in this old historic landmark on higher
education in America. Owing to the serious
losses sustained by the college during the
Civil War, the institution had to be closed.
It is rather curious to note, that although all
work had ceased entirely, the President, the
sole survival of the faculty, used to ring the
old chapel bell at sunrise on the first day of
the autumn session each year.
It was at,this old institution that the study
of history and politics was developed and carried on long before the Northern institutions
even considered such a course. It was here
that were trained the Southern statesmen of
the old regime—such as John Randolph and
Chief-Justice Marshall.
Professor Adams suggested in his monograph that William and Mary be revived as
a training school for statesmen, a West Point,
as it were, for the development of diplomatists.
He urged that such courses of study should be
followed as would prepare men for public life,
and also for the civil service. Professor
Adams' rocommendations were never entirely
carried out, but his monograph attracted widespread notice. Copies of it were put into the
hands of the members of the Virginia Legislature, and public pressure was brought to
bear to such an extent that an appropriation
was made for the revival of the college. Since
its reopening the institution has been doing a
valuable work as a normal college; special attention being laid on the training of teachers
for the public schools. The students taught
at public expense—this class includes by far
the largest number—are required to teach in
the public schools of the State for at least two
years. This system has secured for the State
an efficient corps of public teachers.
At the present session of the Legislature, a
bill was reported favorably which would re-

5

duce the annual appropriation from fifteen
thousand dollars to seven thousand and five
hundred, on the grounds that the work being
done did not justify so large an appropriation.
There also seems to be a sentiment current
among quite a large number of the members
of the Legislature to do aWay entirely with
appropriations, and even to confiscate the college buildings and chattels, despite the decision of the United States Supreme Court on
the famous Dartmouth College case, declaring
the invalidity of such a course. It is to be
hoped that such unjust measures will not be
employed. William and Mary's record in the
past has earned for it the financial and moral
support of the State.
It seems only right that those collegiate institutions which have contributed to the intellectual, and even the material progress of a
State, should not be allowed to suffer from neglect and ingratitude in times of adversity.
The Maryland Legislature would also do well
to take it to heart that those institutions within
the State which have so ably stood for higher
education—yes, so ably that Maryland and
Baltimore have become much more widely
known and famous for being the seat of
them—should not have their future operations
cramped and retarded by unfortunate unforeseen financial troubles.
Professor Adams was delighted with his
trip. While there, he was initiated into the
mysteries of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. It
is interesting to note that this society—the
oldest of its kind in America—was founded at
William and Mary in 1776.

NEEDS OF THE UVM.

Complete and convenient as the equipment
of the new gymnasium is, there are yet some
little things to be wished for. In the lockerroom, which is heated from above, the cement
floor is always cold. When the bare-footed
gymnast first steps on it he is chilled suddenly
and from this several have already caught
colds. Strips of coarse matting spread before
the lockers would not be expensive, and would
do much to remedy the evil.

ATHLETIC rlISCELLANY.

Arrangements have been made for putting
a track in the cage. The track is to be a cinder
one, built under the guidance of Mr. Mackdermott, whose experience in this line is invaluable. The track will be a most welcome
addition to the cage, especially in view of the
fact that many of the runners are now complaining of twisted ankles and sore muscles,
caused by the very uneven ground and sharp
curves of the cage.
The hockey team's trip to Philadelphia failed
to result in any victory for the Black and Blue.
The men, nevertheless, made a very good
showing when it is considered that over half
the regular men were laid up. The first game
with the strong University of Pennsylvania
team was very close, and the second game
which was more one-sided, was played almost
entirely with scrubs.
Professor Doyle of the Baltimore Athletic
Club will today begin instructing the students
in the art of wrestling. We may justly expect
to develop some clever wrestlers under the
experienced, scientific care of Professor
Doyle.
On Tuesdays and Thursdays classes in fencing will be held.
The classes in gymnasium work have become so large that Dr. Crenshaw is obliged to
have two assistants to aid him in instructing
the many new students. The assistants are
very capable men, two of the best gymnasts of
the Turnverein Vorwaerts. This extensive
interest in gymnasium work proper is very
gratifying, and will surely develop many
"dark horses."
Mr. T. F. P. Cameron,'94, and Mr. F. Lupton, Medical School, are daily to he seen playing lacrosse in the cage. Their presence is
especially effective in stimulating the new material.
Mr. Murkland, who recently broke his ankle
in the cage, is rapidly convalescing, and, it is
hoped, will be back at the University very
soon.

Much interest is manifested throughout the
Medical School in regard ,to the anti-vivisection bill now pending before the Senate of the
United States. *While this bill would not directly affect the work here, it is feared that its
passage would exert great influence upon the
Maryland Legislature to pass a similar bill. A
petition has been presented in the Senate by
Senator Gorman, signed by the deans of all
the medical schools in the city, and by other
prominent men, including President Gilman
and Dr. Osier, praying against the passage of
the bill.
In the number of the Journal of the American Medical Association for February 5 Dr.
Welch has p'ublished a long article clearly setting forth the arguments against the bill, and
upholding the value of vivisection as it is
practiced in the leading universities, medical
schools and experimental laboratories in the
country. It is the best argument for animal
experimentation published in some time, and

SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION.

Last Thursday's meeting of the Scientific
Association was exceedingly well attended.
The subjects treated were, however, somewhat
abstruse to ordinary mortals. Mr. Waidner,
fellow in physics, discussed the two rival theories as to the nature of cathode rays—the
wave theory and the solid particle theory. He
spoke chiefly of Professor J. J. Thompson's
work, and his conclusions were in favor of the
solid particle theory. Dr. Ames spoke of
some recent work on Roentgen-ray phenomena. He brought out very clearly that we
must believe the X ray to be not a regular,
continuous succession of waves in the ether,
but simply an irregular succession of very
thin, quick pulses in the ether. All the observed effects can be explained on this supposition. Professor Stokes of Cambridge proposed the idea some little time ago, and just
recently Professor J. J. Thompson, also of
Cambridge, has shown that from certain
mathematical deductions we are led to expect

PRESIDENT PATTON'S
MESSAGE.
When President Patton speaks, it behooves
every student to lend an attentive ear, not only
because all that he says is worthy of deepest
consideration, but also because if one does not
listen closely, one fails to hear almost every
fifth word. His style, however, is piquant, and
at times quaint. His premises and conclusions
are clearly marked, and without doubt he believes what he says. For a man to attempt to
speak of Morals and Religion" in any coherent manner, with all his notes for an hour's
talk on a sheet three by four is, forsooth, a
task before which even a Presbyterian minister might hesitate. But President Patton not
only showed that what he said was the product of deep personal thought, but—what is
more essential—he set his hearers to thinking
for themselves. His arguments were striking,
his conclusions are not lightly to be set aside,
and the question comes to every sincere man,
"How does all this affect. me? How am I to

No. xo

convert my convictions into actions ?"
Dr. Patton spoke of "Moral Obligation,"
of "The Good" and of "The Right." He
glanced at the various ethical schools, and
struck off many apt comparisons. He showed
in an incontestable manner that no adequate
idea of moral obligation can be had until you
enthrone the Almighty and put a moral Governor above you. 'Tis then, and then only, that
the idea of obligation can have any true influence in the amelioration of mankind. We find
in our nature a powerful tendency to degeneration, and if we are to journey toward perfection there must be not only an external
standard whereby our conduct may be judged,
but there must be also an equally powerful
force impelling us away from our natural tendencies. A standard of infinite good and right
by which man's finite doings may be counted
can come only from a true conception of the
attributes of an infinite being—a perfect personality. 'Tis in the presence of such conceptions that the edicts of that infinite being will
furnish the force necessary to raise man up out
of the mire of his natural tendencies. The
edict must get its force from the power of the
personality behind it. If you are going to control the personality of man and obtain morality, the law must he given with the thunder of
Mount Sinai, saying: "Thou shalt not."
Some people would lay aside religion and
consider morality as a separate idea. But the
earthquake that pulls the church down will
shake with equal force the foundations of the
ethical lecture hall. Take away religion and
morals will soon disappear. Albeit that morality is instructive, when once you have removed God you have abolished obligatory
morality forever, and all that you have left is
a morality of good form and good taste.
Under such conditions, how long, think ye,
would this world be a fit dwelling-place for
the children of men ?
President Patton omitted any fruitless discussion of "Determinism" or "Libertarianism," but insisted equally upon the infinite

sovereignty of God and upon the free agency
of man. On nothing else did he lay more
stress than upon the fact that there can be no
moral obligation unless there be a subject of
that obligation—free to feel, think and act.
All the morality of the universe resolves itself
into selfhood — the power of self-determination. We are not mere machines. It is necessary for us to realize fully that we can act of
our own accord, even against a prevailing
habit. In a man's character nature determines
much, and habit goes on and determines more,
yet they do not determine all ;
" holds its
own against both. We must have great actions;
let us then, as Emerson suggests, make our
own so. That man reaches the highest pinnacle of character who most truly and fully
translates into actions on this terrestial ball
the thoughts of the most high God.
We must not avoid facts. We must see that
there is a standard by which our actions arc
judged, and an end to which they will carry
us, if they be conformed to that standard. The
standard is the Right," the end the "Good."
Neither of these ideas is to be made- subordinate to the other. They are co-ordinate, and
mutually parallel. But what is the "Good ?"
Every man leans to that which is most desirable to him, and the logical conclusion is that
there is something supremely desirable. Some
seek wealth, because that brings surpassing
grandeur, or immunity from toil, they seek a
surplus of pleasure.
He who tortures his
memory with innumerable languages does the
same thing in a different way. Both seek happiness, and the result is the same, whether it
come from successful shop-keeping or successful word-monging. Is man's destiny, then,
but to be happy? If we look only at pleasure,
we are unable to distinguish between the
heaven of the hog and the saint's heaven. The
hog's manners are to us somewhat unconventional, but,could he speak, would he not reply
that he preferred the freedom of his trough to
the starched stiffness of our dining-rooms? We
cannot say that pleasure is the end of life, but
must find sonic more rational ground for happiness. The end toward which we strive is
moral perfection. In this matter no idea but
one of progress to higher goals can be

thought of. Drummond says : "It is only a
character which is itself developing that can
aid the evolution of the world and so fulfill the
end of life." To such a progress the end must
be infinite ; and this is God. So far as we can
see, the destiny of every part of everybody is
to become, by growth and development, a perfect part. Is it not the same for man as a
whole ? Self-realization is the "Good" to be
reached. The glory of God, which some consider the chief end of man, is not incompatible
with man's self-realization ; on the contrary,
it is to be reached through self-realization.
Since man is made in the image of God, and
God is perfect, the highest honor that man can
pay to God is earnestly to strive to reach the
same perfection.
If the ideal is to be of any value, we must
believe it to be attainable ; we must separate it
from the life of this world, and then we must
conceive another life in which to enjoy it.
Therefore, if the idea be attainable, and the
blackness of pessimism is upon those that
think not so, there must be God, freedom and
immortality. For it cannot be said that character will develop in all its fullness in this life.
That were a time far too short for an evolution
so glorious. We see here only the small green
blade which hut determines what we ultimately shall be. Ultimately—that is a long
way off, but not too long to take into reckoning. When the fires of the sun shall have
burned themselves to ashes, we shall not have
completed our cathedral of character, we shall
still be building.
Will the building last ?
Hear—" He that doeth the will of God abideth
forever."

PROF. ADAMS' ADDRESS.
On the 18th of February, Professor Adams
delivered the Phi Beta Kappa oration at
William and Mary College on the study and
teaching of history. Professor Adams was
especially welcomed there as a guest since it
was largely due to the publication of a monograph by him, that public interest was revived in this old historic landmark on higher
education in America. Owing to the serious
losses sustained by the college during the
Civil War, the institution had to be closed.
It is rather curious to note, that although all
work had ceased entirely, the President, the
sole survival of the faculty, used to ring the
old chapel bell at sunrise on the first day of
the autumn session each year.
It was at,this old institution that the study
of history and politics was developed and carried on long before the Northern institutions
even considered such a course. It was here
that were trained the Southern statesmen of
the old regime—such as John Randolph and
Chief-Justice Marshall.
Professor Adams suggested in his monograph that William and Mary be revived as
a training school for statesmen, a West Point,
as it were, for the development of diplomatists.
He urged that such courses of study should be
followed as would prepare men for public life,
and also for the civil service. Professor
Adams' rocommendations were never entirely
carried out, but his monograph attracted widespread notice. Copies of it were put into the
hands of the members of the Virginia Legislature, and public pressure was brought to
bear to such an extent that an appropriation
was made for the revival of the college. Since
its reopening the institution has been doing a
valuable work as a normal college; special attention being laid on the training of teachers
for the public schools. The students taught
at public expense—this class includes by far
the largest number—are required to teach in
the public schools of the State for at least two
years. This system has secured for the State
an efficient corps of public teachers.
At the present session of the Legislature, a
bill was reported favorably which would re-

5

duce the annual appropriation from fifteen
thousand dollars to seven thousand and five
hundred, on the grounds that the work being
done did not justify so large an appropriation.
There also seems to be a sentiment current
among quite a large number of the members
of the Legislature to do aWay entirely with
appropriations, and even to confiscate the college buildings and chattels, despite the decision of the United States Supreme Court on
the famous Dartmouth College case, declaring
the invalidity of such a course. It is to be
hoped that such unjust measures will not be
employed. William and Mary's record in the
past has earned for it the financial and moral
support of the State.
It seems only right that those collegiate institutions which have contributed to the intellectual, and even the material progress of a
State, should not be allowed to suffer from neglect and ingratitude in times of adversity.
The Maryland Legislature would also do well
to take it to heart that those institutions within
the State which have so ably stood for higher
education—yes, so ably that Maryland and
Baltimore have become much more widely
known and famous for being the seat of
them—should not have their future operations
cramped and retarded by unfortunate unforeseen financial troubles.
Professor Adams was delighted with his
trip. While there, he was initiated into the
mysteries of the Phi Beta Kappa Society. It
is interesting to note that this society—the
oldest of its kind in America—was founded at
William and Mary in 1776.

SCIENTIFIC ASSOCIATION.

Last Thursday's meeting of the Scientific
Association was exceedingly well attended.
The subjects treated were, however, somewhat
abstruse to ordinary mortals. Mr. Waidner,
fellow in physics, discussed the two rival theories as to the nature of cathode rays—the
wave theory and the solid particle theory. He
spoke chiefly of Professor J. J. Thompson's
work, and his conclusions were in favor of the
solid particle theory. Dr. Ames spoke of
some recent work on Roentgen-ray phenomena. He brought out very clearly that we
must believe the X ray to be not a regular,
continuous succession of waves in the ether,
but simply an irregular succession of very
thin, quick pulses in the ether. All the observed effects can be explained on this supposition. Professor Stokes of Cambridge proposed the idea some little time ago, and just
recently Professor J. J. Thompson, also of
Cambridge, has shown that from certain
mathematical deductions we are led to expect
just such a thin, quick pulse. Another remarkable coincidence between theory and experiment which Dr. Ames mentioned is that
presented by the Tiemann effect—a phenomenon, observed this last summer by a Dutchman named Tiemann, in which a source of
light is found to have the character of its emission remarkably changed in the presence of a
strong magnetic field. This peculiar phenomenon can be fully explained by an electromagnetic theory of light advanced about fifteen years ago by Lorentz.
